DataElement.preferredName: SIOP/COG/NWTSG Staging System Wilms Tumor Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of Wilms tumor using the International Society of Paediatric Oncology/Children's Oncology Group/National Wilms' Tumor Study Group staging system.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: SIOP/COG/NWTSG Staging System Wilms Tumor Stage
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A staging system for Wilms' Tumor that combines the International Society of Pediatric Oncology Staging System and the Children's Oncology Group/National Wilms' Tumor Study Group Staging System._An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix._The extent of a cancer in the body. Staging is usually based on the size of the tumor, whether lymph nodes contain cancer, and whether the cancer has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A staging system for Wilms' Tumor that combines the International Society of Pediatric Oncology Staging System and the Children's Oncology Group/National Wilms' Tumor Study Group Staging System.

Concepts.definition: A staging system for Wilms' Tumor that combines the International Society of Pediatric Oncology Staging System and the Children's Oncology Group/National Wilms' Tumor Study Group Staging System.

Property.preferredDefinition: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.:The extent of a cancer in the body. Staging is usually based on the size of the tumor, whether lymph nodes contain cancer, and whether the cancer has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A staging system for Wilms' Tumor that combines the International Society of Pediatric Oncology Staging System and the Children's Oncology Group/National Wilms' Tumor Study Group Staging System._The extent of a cancer in the body. Staging is usually based on the size of the tumor, whether lymph nodes contain cancer, and whether the cancer has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Presence of hematogenous metastases or metastases to distant lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: Presence of hematogenous metastases or metastases to distant lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The assessment of stage III Wilms' tumor was performed after neoadjuvant therapy was given.

Concepts.definition: The assessment of stage III Wilms' tumor was performed after neoadjuvant therapy was given.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Residual Wilms' tumor confined to the abdomen; Lymph nodes in the renal hilum, the periaortic chains, or beyond are found to contain tumor; diffuse peritoneal contamination by the tumor; implants are found on the peritoneal surfaces; tumor extends beyond the surgical margins either microscopically or grossly; tumor is not completely resectable because of local infiltration into vital structures.

Concepts.definition: Residual Wilms' tumor confined to the abdomen; Lymph nodes in the renal hilum, the periaortic chains, or beyond are found to contain tumor; diffuse peritoneal contamination by the tumor; implants are found on the peritoneal surfaces; tumor extends beyond the surgical margins either microscopically or grossly; tumor is not completely resectable because of local infiltration into vital structures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The assessment of stage II Wilms' tumor was performed after neoadjuvant therapy was given.

Concepts.definition: The assessment of stage III Wilms' tumor was performed after neoadjuvant therapy was given.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Wilms' tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely excised; no residual tumor is apparent at or beyond the margins of the excision; tumor thrombus in vessels outside the kidney is Stage II if the thrombus is removed en bloc with the tumor.

Concepts.definition: Wilms' tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely excised; no residual tumor is apparent at or beyond the margins of the excision; tumor thrombus in vessels outside the kidney is Stage II if the thrombus is removed en bloc with the tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The assessment of stage I Wilms' tumor was performed after neoadjuvant therapy was given.

Concepts.definition: The assessment of stage I Wilms' tumor was performed after neoadjuvant therapy was given.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Wilms' tumor is limited to the kidney and completely excised; the tumor was not ruptured before or during removal; the vessels of the renal sinus are not involved beyond 2 mm; there is no residual tumor present beyond the margins of excision.

Concepts.definition: Wilms' tumor is limited to the kidney and completely excised; the tumor was not ruptured before or during removal; the vessels of the renal sinus are not involved beyond 2 mm; there is no residual tumor present beyond the margins of excision.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

Staging is usually based on the size of the tumor, whether lymph nodes contain cancer, and whether the cancer has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A staging system for Wilms' Tumor that combines the International Society of Pediatric Oncology Staging System and the Children's Oncology Group/National Wilms' Tumor Study Group Staging System.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
